data.naming_authority: The German Centre for Integrative Biodiversity Research (iDiv) Halle-Jena-Leipzig
data.title: Species Occurrence Metrics of Invasive Alien Species of Union concern of the European Union at 10 Km based on GBIF records
data.summary:
This dataset covers GBIF occurrences of species listed in the Regulation (EU) 1143/2014 on invasive alien species (IAS), which specifies the measures to be taken by Member States to control IAS (European Parliament 2014).  Initially, the list of IAS of Union concern was adopted in 2016 and has since been updated in 2017, 2019 and 2022. There are currently 88 IAS subject to strict environmental restrictions on their trade, keeping, breeding, cultivation and release into the environment. 

Here, we used the latest updated list of IAS from the European Topic Centre on Biodiversity and Ecosystems (ETC BE) and the European Environment Agency (EEA) available in June 2024. The currently valid scientific name was matched to the with the GBIF backbone taxonomy. Thus, we obtained the accepted GBIF scientific name and the corresponding species key for all species included in the regulation.

We created the CSV cubes of species occurrence through the GBIF API from R, and used the EEA spatial grid at 10 km. We obtained monthly occurrence data for 77 species and calculated the following metrics:
- Earliest date of records
- Latest date of records
data.source:
These are steps to calculate the metrics of IAS of union concern based on GBIF records:

1. The field  "Currently valid full name" from the latest IAS list by ETC in June 2024 was matched against the GBIF backbone taxonomy [1]. Thus, we obtained the accepted scientific name in GBIF and the corresponding species key.  All names had an 'EXACT' match, but four of them were considered 'SYNONYMS'. We replaced all four 'SYNONYMS' with the corresponding 'ACCEPTED' scientific name and species key. 

2. Using the 'Species occurrence cubes' software developed by B3 and GBIF [2], we created species occurrence cubes in a CSV format matching the EEA grid at 10 Km. The query is in a JSON file and available at GitHub as well as the R script to submit the JSON query using GBIF API [3]. Importantly only records for 77 species were found.

3. We loaded the CSV occurrence cubes using the 'b3gbi' library, and calculated the following metrics: earliest date of records, latest data of records, number of records before 2000, between 2001 to 2010, 2011 to 2020 and since 2020. 

4. After rasterization of the metrics, data was converted to the EBVCube format.

Steps 2 to 5 were conducted in R. All scripts are available at GitHub [3]

[1]https://www.gbif.org/tools/species-lookup
[2]https://techdocs.gbif.org/en/data-use/data-cubes
[3]https://github.com/EBVcube/B-Cubed_data_mobilization
